section.title: Resolving Git Merge Conflicts During Upgrade
section.para: When you perform an upgrade, attempts to incorporate new or updated configuration information on top of your existing environment. However, if you have made certain changes to your environment, cannot automatically determine whether to keep your changes or drop them in favour of the new or updated configurations that it wants to put in place. This will result in a merge conflict occurring during upgrade and it will be up to you to manually resolve the conflict before the upgrade can proceed.

This document gives an overview of how to approach the issue of merge conflicts, showing general procedures for determining where the conflict is occurring, alternative methods for resolution, and a fallback procedure for the case where the resolution goes wrong and you need to start from scratch.

For a general overview of how uses Git, see the introductory article in the Installation section . In particular, note how the site branch is the one most used by the end-user, while the hos branch contains the "upstream" source code corresponding to the contents of the ~/helion directory on a pristine fresh installation.
section.bridgehead: Identifying the occurrence of a merge conflict
section.para: If you hit a merge conflict during upgrade, you will observe output similar to the following on the console:
section.screen: Auto-merging hos/ansible/roles/nova-compute-esx/defaults/main.yml Auto-merging hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 Auto-merging hos/ansible/roles/nova-cli/tasks/availability_zones.yml Auto-merging hos/ansible/roles/nova-api/templates/api-paste.ini.j2
section.para: Use git status to see the discover the source of the problem:
section.screen:
... new file: tech-preview/entry-scale-kvm-vsa-mml/data/swift/rings.yml modified: tech-preview/mid-scale/README.md modified: tech-preview/mid-scale/data/control_plane.yml
Unmerged paths: (use "git add/rm <file>..." as appropriate to mark resolution)
both modified: hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: Edit the file hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 to see the conflict markers:
section.bridgehead: Examining differences between your current version and the previous upstream version
section.para: Typically, the previous upstream version will be the last-but-one commit on the hos branch. This version will have been created during the initial installation of your cloud (or perhaps during a previous upgrade). So in total, there are three significant versions of the file:

listitem.para: The previous "upstream" version on the hos branch.
Your current version on the site branch.
The new "upstream" version on the hos branch.

section.para: You can identify the previous "upstream" version using git merge-base
section.screen: git merge-base hos site 2eda1df48e2822533c50f80f5bfd7a9d788bdf73
section.para: And then use git log to see where this commit occurs in the history of the hos branch.
section.screen:
git log hos -- commit 22cfa83f3526baf30b3697e971a712930f86f611 Author: Helion git user <helion@hpe.com> Date: Mon Jan 18 00:30:33 2016 +0000
New drop
commit 2eda1df48e2822533c50f80f5bfd7a9d788bdf73 Author: Helion git user <helion@hp.com> Date: Sun Jan 17 19:14:01 2016 +0000
New drop
section.para: In this instance, we can see that the relevant commit is in fact the last-but-one commit and so we can use the simplified name hos^1 to identify that commit.
section.screen: git diff hos^1 HEAD -- hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: In the diff output, you should be able to see how you changed the value for metadata_proxy_shared_secret from unset to top_secret_password111:
section.bridgehead: Examining differences between your current version and the new upstream version
section.para: To compare your change with the new upstream version from on the hos branch you can use git diff HEAD hos -- <<path/to/file>>:
section.screen: git diff HEAD hos -- hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: In the extract of output below, you can see your value top_secret_password111 and the new value {{ neutron_metadata_proxy_shared_secret }} that wants to set.
section.bridgehead: Examining differences between the new upstream version and the previous upstream version
section.para: To compare the new upstream version from with the previous upstream version from your initial install (or previous upgrade):
section.screen: git diff $(git merge-base hos HEAD) hos -- hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: In the extract of output below, you can see the new upstream value {{ neutron_metadata_proxy_shared_secret }} that wants to set and the previous upstream value unset.
section.bridgehead: Using stage markers to view clean versions of files (without conflict markers)
section.para: You can use the git show command with stage markers to view files without having conflict markers embedded in them. Stage 1 is the previous upstream version (:1), stage 2 is your current version (:2) while stage 3 is the new upstream version (:3).
section.screen: git show :1:hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
... admin_username = {{ neutron_admin_username }} metadata_proxy_shared_secret = unset neutron_auth_strategy = keystone neutron_ca_certificates_file = /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt ...
git show :2:hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2

... admin_username = {{ neutron_admin_username }} metadata_proxy_shared_secret = top_secret_password111 neutron_auth_strategy = keystone neutron_ca_certificates_file = /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt ...
git show :3:hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: There are two approaches to resolving the conflict:

listitem.para: Edit the merged file containing the conflict markers, keeping the change you want to preserve and removing the conflict markers and any changes you want to discard.
Take the new upstream version of the file and re-apply any changes you would like to keep from your current version.

section.bridgehead: Resolving the conflict - editing the file containing the conflict markers
section.para: Edit the file hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 and if you want to maintain your change, then delete the lines in bold below:
Your file should now look like this:
section.bridgehead: Resolving the conflict - re-applying your changes to new upstream version
section.para: Create a copy of the new upstream version (see Stage 3 above) in your working directory:
section.screen: git show :3:hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 > \ hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: Now edit the file hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 and manually re-apply that changes you want.
You may want to check that the changes you have applied are correct. Compare the new upstream version with the version in your working directory:
section.screen: git diff hos -- hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: If you are happy with the resolution, you can stage your changes using:
section.screen: git add hos/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: Apply the above steps to all the merge conflicts you encounter, and when you have them resolved to your satisfaction, complete the merge:
section.screen: git commit -m "complete merge"
section.para: If you make a mistake during the resolution process, you can return your working directory to a clean copy of the site branch using:
section.screen: git reset --hard
section.para: If the new upstream version contains files that didn't exist in the previous version, these files will be left behind - you can seem them using git status. To clean up these files, remove them and then reset:
section.screen: git rm -rf hos git reset --hard
section.para: Alternatively, you can use git stash to save these files to transient stash queue.
